action.action-desc: Mr. King of Iowa introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

form.official-title: To amend section 1951 of title 18, United States Code (commonly known as the Hobbs Act), and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Freedom From Union Violence Act of 2017.

section.header: Interference with commerce by threats or violence
section.text: Section 1951 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to read as follows:

section.header: Interference with commerce by threats or violence

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (c), whoever in any way or degree obstructs, delays, or affects commerce or the movement of any article or commodity in commerce, by robbery or extortion, or attempts or conspires so to do, or commits or threatens physical violence to any person or property in furtherance of a plan or purpose to do anything in violation of this section, shall be fined not more than $100,000, imprisoned for a term of not more than 20 years, or both.

subparagraph.text: commerce within the District of Columbia, or any territory or possession of the United States;
commerce between any point in a State, territory, possession, or the District of Columbia and any point outside thereof;
commerce between points within the same State through any place outside that State; and
other commerce over which the United States has jurisdiction;

paragraph.text: the term extortion means the obtaining of property from any person, with the consent of that person, if that consent is induced—

subparagraph.text: by actual or threatened use of force or violence, or fear thereof;
by wrongful use of fear not involving force or violence; or

paragraph.text: the term labor dispute has the same meaning as in section 2(9) of the National Labor Relations Act (29 U.S.C. 152(9)); and

the term robbery means the unlawful taking or obtaining of personal property from the person or in the presence of another, against his or her will, by means of actual or threatened force or violence, or fear of injury, immediate or future—

subparagraph.text: to his or her person or property, or property in his or her custody or possession; or
to the person or property of a relative or member of his or her family, or of anyone in his or her company at the time of the taking or obtaining.

paragraph.text: Subsection (a) does not apply to any conduct that—

subparagraph.text: is incidental to otherwise peaceful picketing during the course of a labor dispute;
consists solely of minor bodily injury, or minor damage to property, or threat or fear of such minor injury or damage; and
is not part of a pattern of violent conduct or of coordinated violent activity.

paragraph.text: Any violation of this section that involves any conduct described in paragraph (1) shall be subject to prosecution only by the appropriate State and local authorities.

subsection.text: Nothing in this section shall be construed—

paragraph.text: to repeal, amend, or otherwise affect—

subparagraph.text: section 6 of the Clayton Act (15 U.S.C. 17);
section 20 of the Clayton Act (29 U.S.C. 52);
any provision of the Norris-LaGuardia Act (29 U.S.C. 101 et seq.);
any provision of the National Labor Relations Act (29 U.S.C. 151 et seq.); or
any provision of the Railway Labor Act (45 U.S.C. 151 et seq.); or

paragraph.text: to preclude Federal jurisdiction over any violation of this section, on the basis that the conduct at issue—

subparagraph.text: is also a violation of State or local law; or
occurred during the course of a labor dispute or in pursuit of a legitimate business or labor objective.
